p: L. javanica naturally occurs in central, eastern, and southern Africa. Alkaloids, amino acids, flavonoids, iridoids, and triterpenes have been identified from the plant [ 43]. The antibacterial properties of L. javanica can be attributed to phenolic compounds such as apigenin 7, which was highly active against Vibrio cholera, E. faecalis, S. typhi, Proteus mirabilis, and P. aeruginosa [ 43]. Therefore, these results give credence to the use of the species' infusions against bacterial infections including campylobacteriosis.
